Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 05:31AM - edited Dec 13, 2013 05:47AM by mahorgo surgery is beneficial in some cases. You have to see the study referenced in the conference. I have read several studies showing a clear benefit
Posts.Title: Surgery or not? Please help del3 Redmond

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2013 06:30AM - edited Dec 14, 2013 07:21PM by mahorgo Surgery is still a benefit to a subgroup of patients. Say it is not beneficial to anyone it does not seem prudent to root of current studies. The underlying issue is that patient group benefits and what is not necessary. This answer should have your medical team. http://www.upmc.com/media/NewsReleases/2013/Pages/upmc-study-finds-advanced-breast-cancer-patients-benefit-from-surgery.aspx

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2013 12:33PM mahorgo wrote: Thanks for sharing EnglishMajor So, I denovo are a smaller percentage in the initial diagnosis, in addition to which some studies more stable and better survival if you add ER + PR + HER- Your initial metastasis in that place (s) were?
Posts.Title: sternal metastasis (de novo) mahorgo Leah_S

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2015 06:09PM - edited Feb 23, 2015 06:09PM by mahorgo Good news. After my initial diagnosis of breast cancer with metastasis in the sternum (chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation and recently oophorectomy), my scanner is still clean and my bone scintigraphy no evidence of disease. I'm with tamoxifen and now my oncologist suspended my monthly Zometa, since no evidence of metastasis in the sternum. I wanted to share with you.
Posts.Title: sternal metastasis (de novo) mahorgo Leah_S

Posts.Content: mahorgo wrote: hello, I am 40 years old, premenopausal, I was diagnosed with sternal metastasis (de novo). given my response to chemotherapy "I qualified" for surgery (modified radical mastectomy), my margins were negative and I had 4/21 lymph nodes involved. Now I'm waiting to get my mobility in the arm to start radiotherapy and return to systemic therapy tamoxifen. Anyone had an initial diagnosis like me?. regards Dx 5/1/2013, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 4/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
